UNAM:
Heatleeches. If the Settled Systems had a "most annoying" award, they'd be the champ, a hundred years running.  Would you suspect an irritating worm could transform into something with the mass of a backhoe? It's no surprise generations of scientists whiffed on this. But now, knowing what I'm looking for, it's so damn obvious.

The key to their explosive growth: skein cells. Tightly wound bundles of tissue, able to expand explosively at a moment's notice. Plenty of creatures have evolved them independently over the millennia. Hell, Old Earth even had species that utilized them when they were in danger. But the tricks of those species - instantly creating a cloud of slime that's 10000 times bigger than it was a second ago to evade a predator - isn't nearly the same as birthing a whole new creature right before your eyes.

At least, not at first glance.

This is where Heatleeches go from pest to perhaps the most interesting creature in the damn galaxy. In all previously documented cases, the skein cells present in a given species were specialized, usually reserved to one, maybe two particular uses inside the body. But in Heatleeches, they're everywhere. In a couple of the older leech specimens we dissected, every muscle fiber, bone, and nerve was packed with densely wrapped versions of themselves. Under the right circumstances - like the end of a 70-year gestational period, or a shower of Lazarus pollen - the skeins are unleashed, turning little muscles, bones, organs, and nerves into much larger muscles, bones, organs, and nerves, and transforming an otherwise obsequious pile of slithering meat into a walking tank.

This explains their long (standard) gestation cycle. Why it takes near-on a century for them to show on a colonized world. Building up that many little spring-loaded cells takes time and lots of energy. And while we're still decoding the specific mechanisms that do all that hard labor of winding up millions upon millions of skein cells over generations, what we do know is that Lazarus pollen acts as a catalyst for the winding process, launching it into hyperdrive. But with or without Lazarus pollen to speed up its arrival, the final transformation appears to always be the same - rapid and violent.

This also seems to hint at why Terrormorphs look so... unwell. People had always noted that they looked raw. More organs on the outside of the body than the inside. My guess is that this is because their formation requires them to be partially broken down (pretty standard for all natural metamorphoses) and then effectively RIPPED OPEN BY THEIR OWN CELLS as the skeins release. Human adolescence isn't fun, but Heatleech adolescence is something else entirely.

The skein cells, though, they aren't even the most amazing part of the sequence - it's the reassembly. Exceptions abound, but, in general, your average metamorphosis in nature takes from a couple weeks to a couple months. Cells of the nymph get broken down and repurposed to leisurely become a fully formed adult. 

But as we now know, the Heatleech completes this exact same process at the drop of a hat. Every cell and protein knows exactly where to go and the propulsion provided by the skein cells lets them get there at breakneck speed. Imagine a skin graft that could grow and direct itself to damaged tissue in a matter of seconds. Imagine a human body that could clot and heal over a wound mere moments after the damage was dealt. First aid, trauma care, accidental death? Things of the past.

If we could harness this behavior, these little creatures could change human life forever.
....
....
....
Okay, I just reread this, and lady, you are getting waaaaay ahead of yourself. 

But still... can't help getting excited about the possibilities.

___________________________
For the eyes of the Terrormorph Management Division directors only.
Active Directions: 
>> Sanon, Hadrian {Maj.}
>> Walker, Percival {Dr.}
___________________________

It is the responsibility of the facility directors to familiarize themselves with the varying levels of emergency procedures, should the unthinkable ever occur.

Should you find yourself unable to perform the duties of required of director, please report immediately to your supervisor for replacement,

EMERGENCY LEVEL IV: Minor Emergency
Criteria
>> Staff are placed in moderate levels of danger, but risk of exterior contamination is minimal/non-existent.

Response
>> Issue "Clean Up" order. Deploy appropriate staff to mitigate emergency status. Request emergency support from Cydonia if required.

EMERGENCY LEVEL III: Moderate Emergency
Criteria
>> Emergency presents significant risk of exterior contamination, but staff is not in immediate danger.

Response
>> Issue "Safehouse" order and initiate facility lockdown. Order all staff to safe, lockable positions, and unlock access to emergency rations. Activate automated emergency system and wait for arrival of external decontamination team.

EMERGENCY LEVEL II: Major Emergency
Criteria
>> Staff are in extreme danger if left in place, but extraction bears only minimal risk

Response
>> Issue "Evacuation" order. Director is to order all staff to leave the facility, activate the automated emergency systems, and wait in a safe, exterior location for the arrival of external support.

EMERGENCY LEVEL I: Catastrophic Emergency
Criteria
>> Staff are in extreme danger, but evacuation risks possible contamination/harm to civilians elsewhere on planet. 

Response
>> Issue "Safehouse" order and initiate facility lockdown. Order all staff to safe, lockable positions, and unlock access to emergency rations. Activate "Containment" system, sealing off all entrances and exits and activating explosives in the surrounding cavern, preventing escape of all lifeforms.
___________________________

Place to gather your thoughts when you've actually got time to gather your thoughts. 

See you again in 2430, I guess.

One quick one - the past is past. Do not let it slow you down, Hadrian.

Because right now, there's work to be done.

Henry Ferraro
Andres Jensen

Unfortunately, due to circumstances beyond my control, I've been a bit delayed in getting to these, but I wanted to give you a heads up, since you'll be required to send your observations in for comparison. Thanks!

-Dr. Gilly Seong

After the incident occurring after the last employee happy hour, we're going to put all future company sponsored happy hours on hold for the time being. On a related note, anyone who finds a glass eye is requested to bring it up and see me at my desk so I can return it to its rightful owner. Thank you.\n\n-Tia

Sorry, Trevor! That's probably me. Just trying to make people laugh. I'll clean it up a bit. Were the f-bombs too much? I'll cut 'em all out. But you have to admit it's kind of hilarious to hear a robot swear. Anyway! More corny jokes it is!

-Laylah

>>Whoever keeps reprogramming Noam to give snarky answers, please stop. It's okay  
>>to help improve his responses and other functions, but HR has asked that we please 
>>try to keep it work-safe. And giving him unhelpful, snarky responses makes him 
>>less useful. If this keeps up, we'll have to retire him to the scrap heap.
>>
>>-Trevor

I'll get on it and send some down to you shortly.

-Tia

>>I know we're not taking on anymore contracts, but just in case someone drops out

>>I've been trying to get a hold of Peter, and I know he always functions better when

>>
>>-Trevor

BTXT: Security Incident Reports\n
UNAM:
Filed by: J. Walsh, Security Staff
Incident reporter: Dr. Titus Cassidy

Dr. Cassidy claimed that a patient in the VIP wing became confrontational and threatened violence when he tried to administer a medication. I spoke to the patient, Catalina Rivera, and calmed her down. She agreed to take the medication.

BTXT: Security Incident Reports\n
UNAM:
Filed by: P. Taro, security staff
Incident reporter: Rebecca Armistead, RN

Nurse Armistead filed a report that a patient in the VIP was found in an off-limits area. Patient identified as Catalina Rivera was found to be inside a CERV shuttle and was asked to return to her room. Patient cooperated and apologized, expaining she had become lost.

BTXT: Security Incident Reports\n
UNAM:
Filed by: J. Walsh, security staff
Incident reporter: Candace Doolin, patient (filed complaint)

Patient filed a complaint and insisted on speaking to security about a lack of personalized attention and to inform us that her symptoms were not being taken seriously enough. I informed the patient that was a medical matter and not a security issue. Patient said she was aware of that, but did not feel the medical staff were listening to her concerns and had nowhere left to turn. Spent an hour listening to the patient, which seemed to calm her down.

Don't forget to put in that vacation request. It's been too long since we had a break. Can't wait until we have some quiet time at the cabin on Montara Luna. I'm going to fish all day, and then at night, well, you'll see.\n\nLove you.
That last courier ship from Akila brought a slate for you. You were out of your office so I left it on your desk. \n

To all staff,\n\nWe've had a few recent incidents of personnel entering in the VIP wing without authorization. Please respect the privacy of our VIP guests and DO NOT enter the VIP wing without express authorization, no matter what. See me if you have questions.

Did you hear about the bank heist in Akila City? I just read about it on a news slate. I hope nobody we know was hurt or killed. Sounds like the Shaw Gang was behind it, no surprise there. I sure don't miss living on Akila. I'll never take the peace and quiet of the Clinic for granted again.

UNAM:
Dr. Kendrick Lane,

Welcome to the Infinity LTD fold. We hope you'll find the breakthrough research we need to perfect Project Dominion. You came highly recommend by Faye Sengsavahn, our head of Research and Development, so we're very excited to have you with us.

I understand your concerns on these human trials being unauthorized, but I assure you, this is just a minor hiccup. I've been told we're only a few days away from approval, and we'll get those documents to you as soon as possible.

Please remember that all subjects have signed waivers accepting the risks. I hope this will ease any hestitation you may have. The end will justify the means.

Lucas Drexler
CEO: Infinity LTD

Project Dominion requires a compatible alloy that the human brain will not reject when the Internal Neuroamp is surgically implanted.

Goal 1: Find the correct alloy ratio
     * A series of metals have been provided for a wide range of experimentation.
     * We're currently looking into obtaining a rare metal to be delivered at a later date.

Goal 2: Ensure the effectiveness of the internal neuroamp
     * Once implantation is successful, ensure the neuroamp can be used effectively.
     * No side effects should be detected for either the user or the target.

Goal 3: Minimize casualties
     * Infinity LTD understands that severe injuries and even fatalities may be encountered. 
     * Do not let issues hinder research progress. Notify your contact and we'll take care of it.

BTXT: Personal Logs: Dr. Kendrick Lane
UNAM:
Kai's results were initially so promising, but now the poor kid is in a coma. I thought, surely, he would be the light at the end of this grisly tunnel. We've now gone through our entire list of subjects, and I dread the idea that Infinity will just sign up more.

What is going on over there? Has Faye completely lost her mind? I understand when corporations rush things when it comes to household products or maybe office software, but not something that will endanger the lives of others. This Internal Neuroamp may as well be a murder weapon, and I'm the one with blood on my hands. 

Contracts aside, I'm certain this will end in ruin.

BTXT: Personal Logs: Dr. Kendrick Lane
UNAM:
It's hard to believe I once walked into the Clinic with high hopes of what Sean and I would bring about. The concept of the Internal Neuroamp from Faye and promises of fame and fortune provided all the motivation I needed. It blinded me. 

I never should've agreed to start the trials without proper approvals. I never should've dragged Sean into this. 

I see now why it was always such a struggle to get my own approvals for human trials. I also see why the contracts are so complex. I never thought I'd lose a patient on my watch, and here I've lost more than I wish to say. Infinity's legal team has assured me that the contracts the subjects signed keep us clear from any legal repercussions, but since the trial itself is still unapproved, I have a feeling they've little to stand on.

But somehow, the hopefulness remains. After the initial losses, I told myself no more, but Faye would insist her changes to the prototype were solid -- that it should be the last one. I'd find myself with renewed motivation and confidence, only to find another dead at my hands. 

We have three subjects left. They aren't aware of the fate of their predecessors. Faye has informed me her latest prototype is complete and on its way. I can only hope I make the right decision.

BTXT: Personal Logs: Dr. Kendrick Lane
UNAM:
We lost our first subject today. A-01, Bronwyn Meijer. The procedure went really well, but I believe the neuroamp overheated, burning the portions of the brain where it had contact. I sent the results to Faye. She believes she has a solution, but my God. I've never lost a patient before.

I sent everyone home. Sean wanted to stay, but I told him to go. I know he needed to process what happened, too, and I didn't want to hold him back. I tell myself it was the neuroamp. That it wasn't my fault. But if it feels like an excuse, it must be.

And what will happen now? These trials aren't even approved and I already have a death on my hands. I thought I was signing up for new advancements in neuroscience, but if I'm not careful, this could ruin what I have left of my career.

BTXT: Personal Logs: Dr. Kendrick Lane
UNAM: Today marks the start of a new adventure in neuroscience. Although Infinity LTD is still waiting for official approval, we're moving forward with testing their latest technology: an Internal Neuroamp. I can't tell you how excited I am to be on a new project and have a chance to regain some admiration among my colleagues. \n\nI've invited Sean to come work with me on the project since he's familiar with how I operate. Plus, like myself, I knew he could really use the credits. These procedures should be quick and simple, so it's really a matter of Infinity LTD's tech playing nicely with brain tissue. Dr. Faye Sengsavahn is the creator of this new neuroamp and she's assured me smooth sailing. Let's just hope with our combined expertise we find success. This could be the boost my career needs.

Subject: A-10
  Name: Kai Porter
  Age: 23
  Status: Coma

Version Implanted: v3.5
  Experimental Alloy: Titanium Grade 128

Notes:
Initial procedure was successful. Patient reported no changes for the first four days. Brainwaves were normal. Cognition tests were 100% across the board. Testing the neuroamp on day five appeared to bring on severe headaches with eventual brain hemorrhaging. Neuroamp was removed to prevent death, but patient is currently in a coma.

Subject: A-09
  Name: Jacinda Carrodine
  Age: 25
  Status: Deceased

Version Implanted: v3.3
  Experimental Alloy: Titanium Grade 125

Notes:
Procedure was a success and all vitals were normal for the first day. Rejection of the implant started approximately 37 hours after surgery. I believe A-09 inadvertently used the neuroamp on a staff member who reported severe dizziness. Emergency surgery was performed to remove the neuroamp, but experienced brain death shortly after removal.

Subject: A-08
  Name: Osmia Leinhart
  Age: 22
  Status: Deceased

Version Implanted: v3.0
  Experimental Alloy: Titanium Grade 120

Notes:
Initial procedure appeared successful, but signs of edema began approximately an hour after the surgery. Initial attempts to stabilize through the med pod failed and condition worsened rapidly. We began surgery prep, but A-08 experienced complete brain failure before we could operate.

Did you see the reviews? These excerpts below are unacceptable and need redaction. This is a disaster. I need you to get in contact with all publications and get this rectified. 

"This latest attempt at the ultimate tourist attraction in space, a Zero-G casino that hopes to keep the drinks flowing and the credits rolling, ultimately feels like antiquated entertainment from the dimming lights of our ancestral city of sin..."

"I float my way to the lower level, to spend these lavish moments yanking a lever in hopes of rewarding myself with some credits. With nowhere to plop down my once rotund back pockets, I hover aimlessly in front of a bright black hole, where credits get pulled in with no hope of escaping. I insert my last few creds to be leeched from my now depleted bank account from the overpriced drinks..."

"To my surprise, I hit a match 3 and maybe luck is on my side. The surprise quickly fades to disappointment, as my payout is something surprisingly tangible. It is an official casino marked coin. Unlike the convenience of the CredStik, I must carry a handful of these cumbersome coins, which feel grimy between my fingers. Perhaps the owners thought the feeling of old age tender would make me feel accomplished. Instead, the thought of trading precious creds for any type of physical currency would make anyone born within the last 300 years angry, enough to want to eject themselves out into the vacuum of space rather than spend another minute here..."

Hi Clarence,

As the higher ups said in the last meeting, we are going to have to cut costs across the board. So absolutely no jackpots whatsoever. We're going to set a winning combination this week, but make sure we don't hit any of these. Below are the numbers you need to set:

Winning numbers are:
12, 19, 36, 5

Thanks

Request: Exterminate biological invasive species

Date: 11.15.2308

Requirements: License for Chemical Exterminations (acquired)

Notes: Required drilling into soil at key locations using a laser cutter and depositing poisons. Encountered some minor resistence from wildlife. Barrett set up an outpost for efficient delivery of the chemicals. Local biologist reported complete success 11.30.2308.

Notes: Rumors did not turn out to be accurate.

BTXT: All information is confidential.\n\n
UNAM:
Request: Exterminate aggressive alpha predator

Date: 06.10.2309

Requirements: Hunting License (filed at Town Hall)

Notes: Received request from the local mining company. Creature has been terrorizing miners. Alpha predator may be eusocial, like a queen bee. If it is killed, the hive would also die out.

Hephaestus ordered the immediate closure of this mine and all others in the area even though we are at peak extraction and efficiency.

Mine will be sealed in the standard fashion. All equipment unrelated to extraction is to be left behind.

Mine #H-363 has been decommissioned.
Helgi unexpectedly quit today citing ethics violations on a "planetary scale."
Ervin's contract is over and no more predators -- or any wildlife -- have been found at the mine. It's a miracle!

Year 1 is complete. We are now at full production. Site is expected to be fully depleted far ahead of schedule due to the removed complication of volatile gasses.\n\nNew estimated depletion date: 01.25.2309

Ervin Madani was able to kill the largest of the Predators. Currently no wildlife is at the mine anymore.\n\nUnrelatedly, the volatile gasses from the extraction point are now fully depleted. This did not happen at the previous mines.

05.20.2309 \n\nHephaestus has hired Ervin Madani to kill one of the main predators that hasn't left the area for weeks. He will assist Dr. Helgi Haukkson who is studying the strange predator behavior.

04.17.2309\n\nLarge Predators have been circling the mine and attacking each other. Purpose is unclear. They are very violent and Security from Gagarin Settlement is unprepared for this, so they left. We sent for further assistance. This could disrupt extraction.

02.25.09 \n\nMine #H-363 sent for Security today when one of those local predators arrived to feast on the collection of dead carcasses nearby. We have started to burn their corpses in hopes that it will go away.

02.10.2309 

The volatile gasses that were previously requiring special protective gear have plummetted below critical levels for the 4th straight week, as is the trend with mines after the 1st year of operation.
01.15.2309\n\nThe crew found a flock of dead creatures around the entrance to the mine today. They seemed diseased or starved, but we don't know why they came to the mine.

12.25.2308 

Exactly on time -- 6 months to Phase 2. We have penetrated the subsurface layers of slime and biomass below the top layers of materials, and have full local access. 

Gasses are escaping through the bacterial layers at a rate higher than the previous mines in this biome, but that has assisted in reducing the amount of biomass.

Dr. Haukkson is investigating.

08.07.2308

Dr. Helgi Haukkson has been assigned to the current active Hephaestus Mines to evaluate the situation with the subsurface bacteria. He has full authority to conduct any experiments needed.
06.25.2308\n\nMine #H-363 has been commissioned for the standard 2 year contract, or until the extraction is complete.

Details: 
This is a highly intelligent alpha predator that seems to have recently emerged near the newest Hephaestus Mine. 

Contact: 
I've been assigned to work with Dr. Helgi Hauksson to uncover why the creature is so aggressive, and whether it has anything to do with the mine's activity in the area.

Sweetheart, 

I know this is going to be a long job on Gagarin, so I thought I'd send you some flowers to cheer you up. I know how much you like the ones that aren't cut, and I found someone there who had a live plant. Tada!

Don't worry about me, Aja's got me on a new assignment already with Sarah. That'll keep me busy until you return home. 

Missing you always,
Barrett

BTXT: Commissioned Studies
UNAM:
09.01.2309

Conclusion: 
Biochemical analysis of subsurface bacterial colonies reveals near total collapse caused by the gasses released by the mining processes. 

Killing Apex Predators devastates a local colony temporarily, but they can rebound. 

The chemicals released from the mines, however, are 95% responsible for the collapse of the ecosystem. 

My full report including data, methodology, and analysis will be sent directly to the main office.
-- Dr. Helgi Hauksson

BTXT: Commissioned Studies
UNAM:
08.01.2309

Summary: 
The Apex Predator species is an important component of the Gagarin ecosystem. The species is eusocial and has a strict caste structure with drones, defenders, and a primary reproductive Gyne, or "Queen." 

The Gyne of each region reproduces irregularly, and waste produced by the nesting process is used exclusively by the soil microbes to form massive colonies below the surface. 

Full report sent to main office.
-- Dr. Helgi Hauksson

BTXT: Commissioned Studies
UNAM:
07.01.2309

Summary: 
Below the surface of Gagarin exists a vast microbial colony network that spans much of the planet. These colonies contain many species of microbes working together to convert dust and organic material into soil. Without these colonies, Gagarin's entire ecosystem would be devastated.

Full report sent to main office.
-- Dr. Helgi Hauksson

BTXT: Commissioned Studies
UNAM:
06.01.2309

Summary: 
If a local "Queen" (Gyne) in the regional hive of Apex Predators dies, one of the drones is promoted to Queen by consuming the remains of the previous Queen. The process of promotion takes several months.

Full report sent to main office.
-- Dr. Helgi Hauksson

From: Receptionist Mark\n\nHey Rhonda, looks like we made the cut, huh? Damn shame about Phillip though. He was just starting to fit in around here, too. These cuts are pretty ridiculous, but better than not having a job! Anyway, got to get back to work. Hope we can still go out sometime. Just let me know.

From: Receptionist Mark\n\nI hope you had fun last night. DJ BorealUS was amazing... and the Aurora only made the experience better. Sorry I got cold feet after you asked me up to your place, it's just that I don't think it's right. Not until I break up with Finley. I don't want to wreck what we have, but I can't stab him in the back like that. Give me time.

From: Security Officer Finley\n\nSo you're the one that's taking Mark away from me, huh? I don't know why you lured him away from me like that, but I sincerely hope this kind of a thing never happens to you. It hurts. It really does. And guess what else? I have connections to Neon Security and I am going to make Mark pay for what he's done to me. You wait and see.

From: Security Chief Yates\n\nIt's come to my attention that Mark Griffiths in Reception has been tapping into the accounting system and syphoning funds to his personal account. Mark has been terminated, effective immediately. I wanted everyone to know that we take criminal acts very seriously at Generdyne, and this should be an example for everyone. If you have any questions, please direct them to my inbox.

==Generdyne Power Core Status==

Storage Cell 01 - Green (Maximum Capacity)
Storage Cell 02 - Green (Maximum Capacity)
Storage Cell 03 - Green (Maximum Capacity)
Storage Cell 04 - Green (Maximum Capacity)
Storage Cell 05 - Yellow (Active)
Storage Cell 06 - Orange (Active)

From: Ayumi Komiko\n\nAccording to last month's budget reports, you've spent over ten thousand credits, and have nothing to show at the review. This has to stop. For the last two years, you've been promising some kind of "breakthrough," yet you have absolutely nothing to show for your supposed efforts. I've spoken to Mr. Harada, and we're both very disappointed, but willing to give you another chance. You need to bring us something tangible.

From: Technician Hedlinger\n\nBreyson, we've had to pull Storage Cell 04 offline again today for a full diagnostic. According to our figures, it's reporting only a ninety-three percent efficiency rating which indicates that it's slowly but surely in a process of degredation. We must get the budget to fix these aging power cells, or in a few years' time, we could be looking at a total plant shutdown.

From: Technician Albertson

As per your request, here is the status of our currently active experiments:

EXP-GDY022 - Failed - Total meltdown of all internal components.
EXP-GDY031 - Ongoing - Recommend replacement of windmill blades due to lightning damage.
EXP-GDY053 - Failed - All test subjects deceased. Order for new subjects placed.
EXP-GDY067 - Failed - Hydrothermic coils overheating, suggest total redesign.
EXP-GDY072 - Failed - Project canceled due to projected costs and lack of personnel.
EXP-GDY074 - Active - Setup complete, request more time to adapt the plants to saltwater.
EXP-GDY077 - Active - Setup ongoing, should be completed within the month.

From: Donald Larren, Larren Construction\n\nThe emergency exit from your office has been completed as per your specifications. The lift should bring you directly to the surface, and can be easily accessed using the standard elevator call system. The cost has been deducted from your personal account as requested. Please let me know if you have any issues with the product.

Our goals for this quarter:

1. Establish culture
2. Perform audit of all activities on the starstation
3. Tighten budget and accounting
4. Improve documentation

As Administrator, it's important to establish the right culture. These are lessons I learned when earning my Master's in Business Administration, as well as during the development of the S.P.E.C.T.E.R. Management System. 

As management, it's our job to SUPERVISE aggressively, PROVIDE the relevant feedback, ENGENDER the appropriate amount of fear, so they CORRECT their behavior and TRAIN their minds to EXPECT your presence, Lastly, REPEAT the process. Using S.P.E.C.T.E.R. management, our researchers will be looking over their shoulder at all times, and subsequently, correct their behavior on their own. 

-- Helena Chambers, MBA, Chief Administrator of Starstation RE-939

As you may have heard, we are changing our evacuation protocols. Lieutenant Abreu will brief all of you with the details. As long as I am the head of this starstation, the safety of management and high ranking officials will remain a priority, and the changes are designed to ensure that outcome.\n\n-- Helena Chambers, MBA, Chief Administrator of Starstation RE-939

I've received the notes regarding Helena Chambers and I'll do my best to address all your concerns at our next meeting. I do understand why it can be difficult to have someone without a scientific background making decisions on the research, but please remember that at the end of the day, we are all pulling on the same rope. \n\n-- Dr. Ricardo Bosch

Hey guys! Not be a worry wart, but I am slightly concerned about the psychoactive properties of species VP-0184 and the potential for involuntary abuse. 

I'm no snitch, but I've noticed a couple of really bizarre proposals as of late, including this one about "xenodigestion?" Not to call anyone out, but who cares how long a person can survive inside some predator's stomach? This isn't the best use of MAST resources guys, I'm sure Ricardo would agree.

-- Dr. Fernando Pena

This might be a coincidence, but the day after we discovered the psychoactive properties of that particular flora, Dr. Baines described this incredibly bizarre dream about being devoured by a snake. But you know how private he is about his research. I didn't push the issue because it's none of my business and because honestly, Dr. Baines scares me.\n\n-- Anonymous

I've managed to convince the higher ups to increase the emergency shuttle count. Hopefully we never use them, and it ends up being the extreme waste of resources they claim it to be. \n\n-- Lieutenant Abreu

I looked over the new evacuation protocols, and why are some of the administrative officials given priority, even over the children? Guys, I understand the importance of safeguarding leadership, but yo, what are we really doing here? This is NOT in line with UC guidelines.\n\n-- Ensign Samuel

I get your concerns Ensign, believe me, I do. But in order to get the extra ship I had to appeal to brass' need for self-preservation. Yes, officials will be given a security escort to the new shuttle, while everyone else will need to bear arms and reach the warehouse port. I understand this isn't a popular decision, but its Administrator Chambers' call. All we can do is try to make the best of it and use the drills to prepare everyone on the station.\n\n-- Lieutenant Abreu

Hey guys! I know everyone on the security team is working SUPER hard and it's much appreciated. But I got an itch that needs scratching, so I gotta ask - is it me, or has security gotten lighter on the station? I know we're still in UC space, but is anyone worried we might be a little exposed out here?\n\n-- Dr. Fernando Pena

Hey Fernando, I noticed that too. I think Helena mentioned something about having us undergo firearm training, which some of my team rolled their eyes at. I don't mind it myself, although I will point out there's children on this station and I don't want them mistaking a Sidestar for a toy.\n\n-- Dr. Nikola Medvedenko

I understand both of your concerns and I wish I had more information for you, but the recent security cuts were not a budget decision, and Administrator Chambers is not to blame. Two of my marines actually got engaged (Emma and Hiroki), and decided they were tired of station life. We'll be bringing in replacements soon, but MAST needs to vet the hires.\n\n-- Lieutenant Abreu
Whaaaat?!!?!?! Congratulations to the newly engaged!\n\n-- Dr. Fernando Pena

Everyone keep in mind with Emma and Hiroki's sudden departure we're going to need everyone to work extended shifts. I apologize for this, but the safety of this starstation is one thing we can't compromise. This will only be for a week, MAST is currently vetting several new hires to replace them.\n\n-- Lieutenant Abreu
Fine with me so long as we get paid.\n\n-- Ensign Pascal
I disagree with Ensign Pascal, Lieutenant. This isn't about pay, it's about our ability to defend the station. We're stretched thin as dental floss here.\n\n-- Ensign Wannamaker

I understand your concerns, and I'm working with the administrative team to improve our evacuation protocols. We'll also be having a number of drills to practice. The scientists may complain, but it's for their own good.\n\n-- Lieutenant Abreu

UNAM:
Okay dusties, we've gathered significant data on the asteroids in the <Alias=targetSystem>, and should meet our projected yields for multiple minerals. 

Here are the estimated figures for all the targeted asteroids. Keep in mind these numbers are cumulative, and will take decades to mine completely.

Iron, Nickel, Gold - <Token.Value=RandomInt03> million tons

Iridium, Platinum, Palladium - <Token.Value=RandomInt01> million tons

Icy asteroids may be used as water sources, as well as provide other rare minerals for excavation. So we should continue to scan for those while we harvest the others.

A reminder from your <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>:

As far as laboratory work goes, I'm sure many of you know the protocols in space, so I won't go over them here. If the <Alias=DerelictShipName> doesn't have the specific equipment you need to conduct your experiments, we'll be sure to add it to the wishlist for the next flight.

Just remember that if you have questions, please bring them up with either myself or the sub-leads. I hope you enjoy your time on the <Alias=DerelictShipName>!

A reminder from your <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>:

Thanks to the hard work of our survey team, we've found a number of possible locations for outposts, and will be making a recommendation to headquarters after some additional scans of the neighboring systems. 

But based on our estimates it will take a total of <Token.Value=RandomInt03> months to ge the project fully operational.

Let's just hope the rest of the mission goes as smoothly as the beginning.

A reminder from your <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>:

Our job is to deliver this cargo and its supplies to the destination intact.

However, as we share the <Alias=DerelictShipName> with other crews, you may have noticed the ship may be stocked with amenities that don't pertain to your particular job. As always, be mindful not to touch equipment you aren't trained on.

I still remember the first time I saw the <Alias=DerelictShipName> at the spaceport.

Looking at it then, the ship felt bigger than all the Settled Systems. And it was, in its own way, because it was a door to the entire galaxy. When I was a part of this crew, I felt so much taller than that kid back in <Token.Name=MiscText03>, on their tippy-toes trying to reach the high shelves.

But now? The ship feels so small. And that's how I know this is going to be my tomb.

The team is still in shock over the Crimson Fleet attack. I can tell even the <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> is having trouble getting the crew to get back to work. 

But we need to do something about the damage to the <Alias=DerelictShipName>'s heat collection systems, or else we'll freeze to death.

I don't want to be heartless, but the crew needs to suck it up and get to work.

We were doing some cleanup when the <Alias=DerelictShipName> collided with that asteroid. I don't know if it was <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> piloting the ship, but now's not the time to point fingers.\n\nEnergy capture is at <Token.Value=RandomInt00>% and dropping. We're relying on our battery reserves in the meantime, but we need the ship's repair systems back online soon.

The oxygen levels are dropping faster than we can repair the <Alias=DerelictShipName>. The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> is trying to rally the troops, but it's hopeless.

<Token.Title=MiscText04>

Now look at me. In the next <Token.Value=RandomInt02> minutes, I'm going to be a nameless corpse, empty and alone.

I can barely hear the <Alias=DerelictShipName>'s alarm anymore. It's just become part of the background noise. 

I remember the last time I felt like this. It was about <Token.Value=RandomInt01> years ago. I was at a party in<Token.Name=MIscText03>. and nearly drowned. 

I remember struggling so hard to get above water. It seemed like I was fighting for hours. But then eventually, there can this moment where everything just... stopped. My mind, my body, and maybe time itself stood still. 

I feel that way now, taking in this last bit of air. Everything's starting to slow down. This time, will it stay still?

A clump of my hair fell off this morning. The radiation's gotten so bad, even spending <Token.Value=RandomInt00> seconds out of a spacesuit will wreck your insides.

And with the scanners down, it's hard to tell which modules are safe. The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> says to keep your suit on at all times just to be safe, but I can't sleep in this thing. It's too uncomfortable. 

It's fine. I look better bald anyway.

The radiation's gotten worse. It's not just hair now, people are vomiting inside their spacesuits. It didn't have to be this way.

<Alias.CurrentName=GenericCorpses[1]>s used to go through training when we were hired. We were schooled on how to deal with various types of emergencies. 

Nowadays we rely on these fancy automated systems, and don't know our heads from our tails. That's how we ended up in this situation. 

If this ship is ever recovered, I hope they download the data logs and bring it back to a technician. Let them know what happened here, and why.

<Alias.CurrentName=GenericCorpses[1]>s on this ship have dealt with a lot over the years, so it made sense for the <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> to have us push through and work overtime.

But in the last <Token.Value=RandomInt00> hours, several members of the team have collapsed from heat exhaustion. We can't fix the <Alias=DerelictShipName> if we're lying face down on the floor, dripping in sweat. 

The only hope is to get the ship's auto-repair functions back online.

Temperature levels are rising fast, and if we don't find a way to fix the computer's automated repair systems, we're going to boil inside this ship.

Some of the crew have started talking about taking their own lives. They're writing slates to loved ones, preparing drug cocktails, etc, But me, I'm having a hard time preparing myself for the end game.

I mean honestly, is this really where I'm going to die?

<Token.Title=MiscText04>

I wish the <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> would take my report seriously. <Alias.Pronoun=DerelictCaptain> tells me it's just the product of being on an older model <Alias=DerelictShipName> but if that's the case, this ship should've been decommissioned long ago.\n\nI don't think we can withstand an attack, collision, or geomagnetic storm. The hull might remain intact, but the damage will lead to corrosive gas leaks, or worse.

The <Alias=DerelictShipName> is on high alert. There's damages to multiple systems onboard, including the mainframe computer network.

<Alias.CurrentName=GenericCorpses[1]>s like us aren't trained in the granular details of starship engineering. Sure, we know a few things about ships, but we mostly rely on the computer network to handle all the technical repairs. 

With the network down, we're helpless.

The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> has informed the crew we're dealing with a minor toxic gas leak. 

<Token.Title=MiscText05>

In any case, <Alias.Pronoun=DerelictCaptain> says fixing the leak takes precedence over the mission, as ignoring it could lead to health issues for all of us.

The toxic gas issue has become more serious than we anticipated. Several crew members have fallen ill.

I'm not sure what went wrong. Either the <Alias=DerelictShipName>'s auto-repair functions didn't kick in fast enough, or we just weren't prepared properly for this kind of mission. Not that the higher ups will care. <Alias.CurrentName=GenericCorpses[1]> deaths are just a tax write-off for them.

If we don't survive this, at least the data will linger. Hopefully someone will download the ship's logs and take it to a technician, so this doesn't happen again.

The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> insists the cargo hasn't changed. But I've seen crates like that before, back when I was working the docks in <Token.Title=MiscText03>. They've got reinforced casing for a reason. <Alias.PronounCap=DerelictCaptain>'s hiding something.\n\nMaybe next shift, I'll take a peek at this "<Token.Name=MiscText00>" the <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> says we're hauling, and see what's really going on here.

We didn't have to check on that derelict ship. Now the <Alias=DerelictShipName> is going to suffer the same fate, its crew torn apart from the inside by the <Alias=Robots[0]>s. The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> is dead, and we're likely next.\n\nThe line on my job title says "<Alias.CurrentName=GenericCorpses[1]>," not soldier. We were never equipped for any of this.

The noises inside the <Alias=DerelictShipName>'s walls just keep getting louder. The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> said we'd <Token.Title=MiscText01> to see who'd go do a maintenance check. \n\nIt's been <Token.Value=RandomInt00> hours and they haven't come back yet. <Token.Title=MiscText02>.

Something's amiss with the <Alias=Robots[0]>s on the ship. I've tried resetting their operating systems and running a system check, but everything comes back clean.\n\nI'm wondering if there's a hardware issue at play here. But anytime you mention "targeting parameters" around the <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, <Alias.Pronoun=DerelictCaptain> goes from zero to panic attack in less than <Token.Value=RandomInt00> seconds. Best to keep this under wraps until I know for sure what's going on.

It started with a bang. Somewhere near the docking port. It was an unmistakable sound, the gunfire from a <Alias=Robots[0]>.

A couple of us managed to hide ourselves for a little while, and shut off the lights hoping their sensors couldn't track us in the dark. But then we started to hear noises, and screams. Now, there's only silence.

That's how it's been for the last <Token.Value=RandomInt00> hours. But we can't hide here in the bowels of the <Alias=DerelictShipName> forever. At some point, one of us is going to have to try and reach the mainframe computer, and initiate a shutdown.

<Alias=DerelictShipName> Primary Docking Port
===============================================

Docking Port Status
====================

Ship Information
====================
Ship: <Alias=PlayerShip>
Ship Status: Operational

The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> gave us notice the shields are down. The cause was likely heavy EM radiation, we think from a nearby <Token.Title=MiscText01>.

Also, this is lower priority, but I think something's wrong with the temperature regulators inside the ship. Everyone's been complaining about the cold, and it's clear its had an effect on the instrument gauges. The readings are way off. I'm going to need to check the maintenance logs and run a diagnostic. 

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

We got hit pretty hard by the Crimson Fleet. <Token.Title=MiscText02>. 

Network systems are down, and we're missing the parts for a full repair. At this rate we're going to have to choose between freezing to death or being bombarded by radiation. It's a longshot, but maybe I can get the mainframe computer to do a fix.

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

The asteroid collision left a lot of systems on the <Alias=DerelictShipName> damaged. For starters, it looks like the engines are busted and life support systems are failing. While oxygen and temperatures are stable for now, we don't know for how long.

We don't have enough materials to fire up the repairs, and the mainframe computer network is down. The crew is scrambling at the moment trying to find a solution.

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

A solar flare's put several key systems offline. Oxygen levels are low, but there's no need to panic just yet.

Right now we've parked the <Alias=DerelictShipName> in the <Alias=targetSystem> so we can do a full audit. Also, the <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> just sent a few people to check on the mainframe computer, and they're doing a diagnostic now. The auto-repair system should handle things.

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

Spacers took out our Grav Drive and the network we rely on for repairs. <Token.Title=MiscText02>. 

But right now, the most pressing concern is our basic life support systems. So long as those are working, we'll be fine. 

The company told us the auto-repair systems on this ship are state of the art, so there should be no reason for concern.

Radiation levels inside the ship are off the charts. I'm not sure what hit us, but the team thinks it might've been a <Token.Title=MiscText01>.

I'm headed to the mainframe computer now to run a full diagnostic, hopefully the network systems are still functioning.

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

We thought they were a distressed ship. But as soon as we docked, they tried to board us.  Damn zealots. <Token.Title=MiscText02>. 

We managed to escape but jumped right into a solar flare. With half our radiation shielding disabled, things are looking grim.

With levels so high, the food and water on the ship could be contaminated. I tried eating a<Token.Name=MiscText03> and was vomiting for the next <Token.Value=RandomInt01> hours.

We collided with some debris orbiting the area. It might've been a derelict ship or abandoned satellite, the team isn't sure.

Some of our core systems are offline, and diagnostic says the radiator is offline, which explains the heat. We think diverting some power from the Life Support Systems might help keep temperatures down.

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

This ship has the worst luck. We were attacked by Va'ruun zealots the moment we arrived. There's no rhyme or reason to any of it. What kind of god attacks a civilian ship and leaves it for dead?

At least we managed to escape, but that doesn't mean we're going to survive. Running a diagnostic, it looks like the ventilation system is having trouble removing excess heat from the <Alias=DerelictShipName>. It feels like we're being boiled alive in here. The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> thinks we can fix it, but it's been <Token.Title=RandomInt03> hours and we have nothing to show for it.

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

A spacer ship hit us with a few missiles and knocked out our Thermal Control Systems.  <Token.Title=MiscText02>. 

Temperatures are out of control. Right now, we're trying our best to get the propulsion systems online so we can grav jump out of the <Alias=targetSystem> system and to a nearby spaceport.

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

The <Alias=DerelictShipName> suffered some damage after the last grav jump. I'll have to check the maintenance logs, but it was likely some kind of <Token.Title=MiscText01>.

There's been reports of a corrosive gas leak, but we don't know the source.

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

The <Alias=DerelictShipName> got hit by some debris while the crew was doing maintenance. This morning we found a corrosive leak in one of the pipes near the docking module. 

I'll have to check the mainframe computer and run a full diagnostic check, but we're running low on supplies and we may need outside help to get this repaired.

It's a hail mary, but the crew is taking shifts on the comms and hailing any ship that might grav jump into <Alias=targetSystem> system.

The <Alias=DerelictShipName> got hit by some debris while the crew was asleep. The collision shook up the entire crew, but that was just the start of things.

After an inspection this morning we found a corrosive leak near the cockpit. It looks like we're parking the ship in the <Alias=targetSystem> system until we address the problem. We'll have to check the mainframe computer and run a full diagnostic check.

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

This all started when we got attacked by Spacers. Their ship jumped in while we were doing routine maintenance. <Token.Title=MiscText02>. 

The shields are offline and power is minimal, but without engine support we're stuck in the <Alias=targetSystem> system for the foreseeable future.

We're funneling everything to the life support systems but there's only so much we can do. And now the ship's detecting a toxic gas leak. I'm going to check the mainframe computer and see if we can't pinpoint the source. 

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>'s lost their mind. First there were the delays. Then to make up for it, <Alias.Pronoun=DerelictCaptain> had us take a so-called shortcut through the asteroid field, and now we're paying for it in spades. 

It's not just the damage we can detect, it's all the systems that are still functioning but on the verge of collapse. I'm going to propose a full audit of the ship once we get back home. I just hope it's not too late for that.

The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> had us investigate a distress call in a neighboring system on our way to <Alias=targetSystem>. After docking with their ship, we ended up taking on some of the crew. It's not within mission parameters to take on charity cases, but they looked like they were in dire straits. 

In fact, a few them complained they hadn't eaten for <Token.Value=RandomInt01> days.

I believe it. I offered one of them a <Token.Name=MiscText03> and they nearly took my arm off grabbing it from my hand.

The whole thing started about <Token.Value=RandomInt00> days ago, with scratching noises by the docking port.

Thought it might've been heat leeches, or just the ship being old. 

But now the ship's internal systems are going haywire. I'm wondering if whatever that noise is, it's gotten inside.

The <Alias=DerelictCaptain> notified us we were changing course. It was pretty unusual given the mission parameters, but apparently we got a distress hail from a nearby ship.

Unfortunately, by the time we got there, the ship was derelict. 

It's been <Token.Value=RandomInt00> days since, and we're back doing our jobs. But something's off. We haven't had any collisions or storms coming through, but there's been damage to the ship nonetheless. We should run a diagnostic and check the maintenance logs. The scans might detect something.

We brought home some critters we picked up from the last planet we restocked at. Cute little things, but hungrier than any xenofauna I've ever encountered. 

They'll eat just about anything. I've been giving them <Token.Name=MiscText03> and they inhale it pretty quickly. 

The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> says to stop it but I don't see the harm.

The solar flare seems to have done a number on the systems. Worse yet, the bug's extended to the robot personnel on board.

I've documented some of what I've noticed, from ignoring commands to botching basic tasks.

I'm thinking it may be wise to have their systems shut down and recalibrated, but the <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> feels we need their support to finish the repairs. I'm due for a promotion soon, so I'm not going to argue with <Alias.PronounObj=DerelictCaptain> or raise any further objections. But that doesn't mean I'm not worried.

Ever since the accident we've been having trouble with the network systems on board. 

The technicians are looking into it but the machines are having trouble responding to basic commands. Right now we're pouring over the handbooks looking for a solution.

<Token.Title=MiscText00>.

The ship's navigational system's completely messed up right now thanks to the nearby <Token.Title=MiscText01>.

The <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>'s started the process of aborting the mission, but with the grav systems in disrepair it might be a moot point. 

In the meantime, I'm going to fire up some of the robot crew to help us getting some of these systems online. Hopefully they weren't damaged in the storm.

Mission Status: On hold
Days Remaining: <Token.Value=RandomInt03>

Ship: <Alias=DerelictShipName>
Crew Members: <Global=SE_GenericDerelict_CrewGlobal>

The damage to the <Alias=DerelictShipName> is extensive, but there is one bright side. <Token.Title=MiscText04>. Problem is, even though we know where it stems from, we can't find the parts to fix it. 

While we managed to get some of the base systems online by jury rigging some ship parts, we're going to need a Reactive Gauge if we want to fix the radiator. We should have one stored somewhere on the ship, but if we can't find it, we'll need to craft one.

By my estimates, we only have <Token.Value=RandomInt00> hours before we freeze to death.

<Token.Title=MiscText01>

It doesn't look like we're going to make it. As <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, I feel partly responsible. I can only hope the rest of my crew forgives me.

My body is going numb and my fingers are turning blue. I can't even hold the tools I need to craft this gauge.

<Token.Title=MiscText02>

<Token.Title=MiscText04>. Sadly, it doesn't look good. We're going to run out of air if we don't do something about it soon. The team says we'll need to craft a new Adaptive Frame using whatever materials we can gather. The rest of us are scouring the ship for a spare. I feel like there should be one somewhere on the ship.

Regardless, based on our calculations, if we don't do it in the next <Token.Value=RandomInt00> hours, we won't have enough air to stand, let alone finish the repairs.

<Token.Title=MiscText01>

I hate to say it, but things are looking grim. We didn't get the ship fixed in time, and the oxygen is all but depleted. Some of the crew have decided to take matters into their own hands. I told them I wouldn't stop them. \n\nBut I'm going to ride it out though until the end and hope for a miracle. I just want to see <Token.Title=MiscText03> again one last time.

<Token.Title=MiscText05> Hair loss, bleeding from the gums, and bruises under the skin. \n\nWe've got maybe <Token.Value=RandomInt02> hours to fix the <Alias=DerelictShipName>, but repairs have hit a standstill. We need to replace one of the Control Rods in the ship reactor systems to help absorb the excess radiation, but we don't have the materials to craft one. There might be a spare somewhere on the ship though, just gotta keep looking.

I've heard stories that back on Earth, when a ship took water, it was the Captain's responsibility to go down with the ship. And as <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, I guess that duty falls on me. It's just unfortunate the rest of the crew will share that distinction with me.

Look, I don't want to say I've given up, but the situation on the ship is bleak. The <Alias=DerelictShipName>'s computer network is down, and most of the crew is too sick from the radiation to finish the repairs.

<Token.Title=MiscText02>

<Token.Title=MiscText04>. That's the good news. The bad news is, everyone's been struggling with various symptoms, from dehydration to dizziness to headaches, but we've got to press on.

After the next break, I'm going to have our crew spend the next <Token.Value=RandomInt01> hours just trying to work on the ventilation issues. According to the mainframe computer, we're going to need more Isotopic Coolant to help dampen this heat. 

But that requires ionic liquids, rare tetraflourides, things we don't have on in ready supply on this ship. If we can't craft one, maybe we have some leftover in one of the containers.

Most of the crew is suffering from heat exhaustion. As <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> it's my responsibility to look after them until the end, but I think right now, we all just want to be left alone, so we can pass in the manner we choose to. 

I think I'm going to ride it out in the cockpit and drink this bottle of <Token.Name=MIscText00>.

It won't help with the dehydration, but it'll help with everything else.

<Token.Title=MiscText04>. Namely, the corrosive gas leak. But with the network systems offline, we don't have access to the <Alias=DerelictShipName>'s automated repair systems.

I'm not a medical doctor, but as <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, I've asked the team to watch for symptoms of corrosive gas poisoning, which I've listed here:

- Nausea 
- Vomiting
- Shortness of breath
- Confusion
- Blurred vision

As for the ship, we need a Semimetal Wafer to restore the panel insulation and prevent further corrosion. There should be a spare on the ship, but if not, we'll have to craft it.

The gas is starting to flood the cockpit. It's probably too late.

I don't know what to even say here. You would think on the verge of death, I'd have something profound for my epitaph, but the words escape me.

Wish I was back in <Token.Name=MiscText03>. Maybe in the next life, I'll see the sky from its port again.

We've found the source of the toxic gas leak. Sadly, as far as fixing it goes, we don't have access to the <Alias=DerelictShipName>'s auto-repair functions, because the mainframe computer network is offline.

We're going to have to go about the repairs manually. Once we plug the leak, we'll need to reinforce the hull and replace the Power Circuit that regulates the shields so they're always online. We probably have a spare somewhere on the ship, but if not, we'll have to craft it.

It's a lot of work for a crew that's working in a toxic environment. <Token.Title=MiscText05> I've listed a few of them here.

- Nausea 
- Vomiting
- Headaches
- Fainting

I've instructed any crew members who are free of symptoms to work double shifts to ease the pressure off the others. But I feel like that may be putting too much pressure on the right leg to compensate for the left.

<Token.Title=MiscText01> The gas has found its way into every module. I don't know if there are any survivors. It may be cowardly for the damn <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> to hide in the cockpit, but the only thing I can do is wait here and hail any ship that jumps into the <Alias=targetSystem> system.

We're all trapped inside this coffin, drifting to nowhere. The more the gas pours in, the more I can feel it choke my lungs.

<Token.Title=MiscText02>

When it comes to the crates, the crew is on a need to know basis. 

Fact is, I've been working this side job for the last four missions. There's the regular work, and there's the shipping of this xenofauna. One job provides the perfect cover for the other.

That is, so long as the crew doesn't start asking the wrong questions. Otherwise there may need to be some shuffling when we get back to <Token.Title=MiscText03>. As <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, that's within my authority.

We saw the ship as soon as we grav jumped from <Token.Name=MiscText03>. Some of the crew said we should leave well enough alone, but as <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain> I made the decision to search the vessel for any survivors.

Now I'm worried we brought something on board. After all, it's also my duty to bring the crew back safe to <Token.Name=MiscText02>. 

Hopefully, I'm just being paranoid.

There's been reports of damages across the <Alias=DerelictShipName>, and I don't have an explanation for how or why it's happening.\n\nWe had a full audit done by the engineering team before we left. <Token.Title=MiscText01> Whatever happened, it was after we left orbit. And judging by the claw marks, I don't think this is from a solar flare.

The creatures have overrun the ship. I don't know how the crew died, but I know I'm all that's left, based on the ship's manifest. Watching the number tick down to zero, I felt completely helpless. 

Management told us the ship was equipped to deal with situations like this, but the sonic emitter is damaged and access to the mainframe computer is blocked.

If I want to survive this, I'm going to have to go out there and turn it on.

<Token.Title=MiscText04>.

Apparently the machines are having trouble with their sensor modules, including targeting parameters. This may be related to the damage the ship suffered recently, but we'll need to run a full diagnostic to confirm.

As <Alias.CurrentName=DerelictCaptain>, I've made a decision to pause operations and remain in the <Alias=targetSystem> system until the matter is resolved.

<Token.Title=MiscText01>

The <Alias=Robots[0]> have started attacking the crew. I've tried to re-adjust their targeting parameters but nothing the network is down.

I've holed myself up in the cockpit, but I'll need to get to the rear decks to fish out some repair parts. Once I get the maInframe computer online, I can run a shutdown, but the odds of me making it out alive are slim to none.

<Token.Title=MiscText02>

I went to lunch with Ularu yesterday, and it was strange. I could sense something was off, but she denied it. Refused to tell me, as usual. I wonder what's up with her. It wasn't like her usual moods where she's questioning herself and her abilities.

I've been having a few moments of disorientation lately. It's as if I spaced out completely. Perhaps it's these mind-numbing quarterly reviews. I'll have to make an appointment with my doctor just in case. Maybe even bring this up to my therapist.

I know Yuko's been telling Lane all sorts of confidential information. Lane is pretty clean according to his files, and if anyone can get a bead on someone, it's Yuko. I guess we all need a sounding board. I took a peek inside her own files and, no surprise, she has an eye on him at all times. I don't get her obsession with watching us.

My Dear Ularu,

I believe I have a package of great importance that belongs to you. Shall we arrange for a pickup? 

- S

Hey Ularu,

I was able to confirm that Tomo Higashi did NOT have adequate supporting data for his last report. It looks like he built his own theory off a handful of observations and what he claims as "experience." Good thing Imogene rejected it, right?

That's his third offense, so Imogene and I both agree to recommend him for termination. I know you like to do the honors.

Yuko

Ularu,

Here are the confirmation numbers you wanted for the following shipments:

- 294739: Arboron NovaSeries: 2 dozen Novablast, 4 dozen NovaLight
- 532516: Audio Slates: 2 crates
- 952452: NeuroTac Mark IV: 4 units

All deliveries are on time. I'll notify you once shipping receives them.

Camden Cho
Operations: Supply Chain Manager
Ryujin Industries

Dear Ularu,

I wanted to personally apologize for my brother's behavior over dinner the other night. I believe he still harbors ill-will toward Ms. Imada, and, as you know, his mind simply isn't what it used to be. I know he rejected your offer of a medical neuroamp to help with his clarity, but I will keep trying to change his mind.

Although our last dinner together was an exception, he truly does enjoy seeing you. Your admiration and respect for him instantly bring back the man I once knew. I hope you'll still see us in the future.

Best,
Oliver

Camden,

As you may have heard, we are acquiring Infinity LTD. Like Tranquilitea and DRONE, I want a satellite office set up for them in the storage area we're currently using. I trust you can handle the logistics. 

Masako Imada
CEO, Ryujin Industries

Camden,

As you may have heard, we are acquiring Infinity LTD. Per Genevieve's advice, we'd like to set up a satellite office here, similar to Tranquilitea and DRONE. We can put them in the unused office area that's currently collecting dust. Genevieve will be in touch the with the details. I trust you can handle the logistics. 

Ularu Chen
CEO, Ryujin Industries

Hey Cam,

I know you like people to go through the proper channels, but I really need a new computer set up for Tomo's old station. Dalton's already secured his current one, and we're looking to hire someone new asap. I'm hoping you can expedite this for your fellow peer. 

Yuko

Camden,

It's been brought to my attention, yet again, that you're being too vocal with your opinions on Neon's Administrator. Please keep in mind that we have several people working here with ties to Bayu, and things said in the office often find their way back to him. You know the importance of our relationship and I expect you to respond professionally whenever business may be associated with him.

Ularu Chen
COO, Ryujin Industries

Camden,

I need the confirmation numbers for a series of shipments.

- Order #45832: Arboron NovaSeries: 2 dozen Novablast, 4 dozen NovaLight
- Order #45904: Audio Slates: 2 crates
- Order #46001: NeuroTac Mark IV: 4 units

Ularu Chen
COO, Ryujin Industries

Dalton,

Tomo Higashi is no longer with the corporation. Please see to the usual search and purge of his office equipment. I don't expect you'll find anything, save proof of his own incompetence, but let me know if you do.

Ularu Chen
COO, Ryujin Industries

Hey Dalton,

One of my tech's ran into some interesting encryption. I was hoping you could take a look and maybe tweak an algorithm or two to help crack it. You know. Simple stuff. I'll owe you lunch.

Yuko

Dalton,

I'd like for you to review the current security levels for our subsidiaries. I've heard rumors that Taiyo engineers may have access to aspects of our R&D database that I suspect Veena had a hand in. While I support her wish to share knowledge, we cannot allow competitors to see this as a backdoor.

Masako Imada
CEO, Ryujin Industries.

Mission Statement\n\nGenerdyne is committed to bringing safe and reliable energy to the entirety of Neon. From residential consumers to our largest industrial clients, we treat each of our customers with the respect they deserve. We provide safe, reliable, and affordable electric service while maintaining the absolute highest standards of conduct, as well as acting with integrity and remaining accountable to our community and the environment. Generdyne actively pursues excellence and innovates to better serve our clients. Our values are part of our daily operations and our promise to Neon.

I believe the Mission is pure. But time is harsh and cruel. The machines break down. Clearly, there is no other reason none of us have succeeded and been sent out into the Settled Systems.

I feel I am close to revelation. Something that will shake the earth. But I am not there yet.

ITXT: I am not the only one
UNAM:
We remember things in our core. All of us. Even the great skeptic Roosevelt I've caught on two occasions saying something that surprised himself.

"I got carried away," he said the first time. And "I must've overheard it" the second.

Is it so strange that truth speaks to us through our body? Of times past? People have believed this since our earliest times. Some of us still believe.

Violet left. She joined the Renegades. She must've been a traitor all along.

Genghis is sly. His feints have counter-feints. But you are not the only one who knows how to handle a blade, Mongol.

The Renegades belief is a sickness that must be cured.

I dreamt of the Kush again last night. The scrub, the trees, the soil. There is something to the sky there that haunts me. And our ancestral home, the Earth, is gone. Loss and grief sometimes overwhelms me. My kingdom is gone. My people aren't a people any more.

One day I would build something new born of the past. A new Kush. Something to inspire wonder for the ages!

But first I must pass the Test. I know one day I will be worthy.

The long hard strategy works. Another has joined our flock.

No matter how many lies Genghis spreads, or doubt Roosevelt fosters... the truth of the Mission cannot be denied. Given time the Believers will triumph by numbers alone.

Roosevelt said he remembers a time when there were but three of us. Now we are Legion. No one can stand against us.

FDR may hide it but he is as quick to draw a blade as I. His greatest weakness is this mask of civility. Yet... Yet he has bested my previous lives at every turn.

As much as I despise it... it may be his greatest strength, too. He tells people what they want to hear, and they eagerly soak it in. Flattery. Two-faced lies.

In every battle we've had, we've had traitors. He gets to people.

I want to shake them. Make them see. These are lies!

Why do you trust the machines? The machines that kill us, the machines that hobble us?

But they are too far gone. And Amanirenas is the worst of them.

There is no convincing them. I will free them in spite of themselves. Even if I have to kill every last one of them to make it so.

It amuses me how nervous I make Ms. Lovelace. But she intrigues me. The robots taught me little of the new science.  So I piece it together with talks with her.

Last night Ada told me of her theories about cloning. About this DNA. Now I wonder if I'm even a clone of Genghis? 

I know from my education that the real Genghis is a mysterious figure. No one knows where he was buried, where he was born, or almost anything.

So how did they capture his DNA? Or did they? One way or the other, I may share his name - but I am my own man.

I found the clues I left for myself. Old Mongol trail signs, invisible to the others.

It is gratifying to know that I never fall in with the Believers. I always rebel. I have tried so many ways to escape, but I cannot find a way. There is no way.

The Facility must be destroyed. That is the only path forward. But how...?

Every week, I visit Wyatt and he shows me the marvels of modern drink. So many flavors, so many varieties! Why did the robots give us such ample provisions in this department?

Wyatt surprised me with what he called "Cactus Wine." We literally howled at the moon!

I will make a Renegade of you yet, Wyatt. You deserve to be free.

Some of the mates have been complaining about watered-down drinks, like it's my fault we're serving this piss.\n\nNot my fault they haven't been putting in the work to keep us supplied the way we should be. Maybe they should spend less time hanging at the bar and more at the Mission Boards.

Naeva's on edge lately. Part of it is vouching for Rake, but she's been burned before. What's bloody changed is the timing. We're spread thinner than marmite right now, and the whole crew knows it. \n\nMaybe this new rook will pan out, but if things keep going bad, it's gonna be like rats leaving a sinking ship.

This whole business with Kryx's Legacy has got the Nova buzzing. Personally, I think it's a whole lot of shite, but if I'm wrong I'll be the first one to admit I was a bloody fool. Had plenty of experience with that losing Maddie already.\n\nAnyway, more creds will mean better drinks, and a cheerier mood around the pub. But if it ain't real, it'll be up to me to drown the sorrows.

The Nova's never been this lively. Hell, even my spirits seem to have climbed a rung or two. Just now some rook called me "Fergus" and I didn't even blow his brains out. Just patted him on the back and poured him another drink. 

In fact, I kind of liked the sound of it. Fergus. Maybe this is a sign from Maddie that I need to retire from this life, and take the name "Bog" with it.

Lots of possibilities either way. It's a new day.

This crew is bloody cursed.

Not only did the new rook turn out to be a rat, they handed the Legacy over to SysDef on a silver platter. Even if we survive this fight, we don't have the creds to survive a war.

Maddie, I'll see you soon love.

There have been growing concerns regarding Crimson Fleet presence in the area. I hope this message will allay your fears. 

Yes, it's true that some Crimson Fleet have been spotted in our system. This is not cause for concern, however. Although it may seem like they are approaching our location, this is impossible. 

You have all been assured that this facility and your work is top secret. This is still the case and will not change. Even if the Crimson Fleet land on the planet, our location is still entirely secret. I assure you that you will all remain perfectly safe. 

In the event of an emergency, you will all be notified as soon as possible of evacuation procedures. However, I do not anticipate ever having to take such measures. 

Please continue your research as normal. If you have any further concerns, please speak with me directly. 

Thank you,

Chief Scientist Feldman

All scientists should be advised that the pirates we have been monitoring have landed planetside. While this is a worrisome development, work will resume as normal. 

We are monitoring the situation and will update everyone on an emergency protocol should it be deemed necessary. However, as of now, you are all expected to resume work.

Please refrain from spreading panic amongst your coworkers and yourselves, and keep conduct professional at all times. 

Thank you,

Chief Scientist Feldman

Habitat Insulation foam
	Habitat Assembly Hardware

	Crew Rations
	Officer Rations (Inform Sgt. Langdon immediately upon landing)

Under no circumstances should members of the construction team be supplementing their meals with rations from the cargo shipments. The rations we receive each week keep us alive through the following week.

In addition, the rations in those shipments are tailored to our crew's individual dietary needs. You all filled out a nutrition form when you accepted this assignment. Do you want to find out what happens when I digest a Butcher's Best Turkey? I don't think so.

The next crew member caught stealing from the cargo containers will be sent into the wilderness to find their own food on this rock.

Sgt. Langdon

UNAM:
WE'RE HERE TO SERVE YOU
As a VIP guest, you'll enjoy the very best hospitality we have to offer. Spacious private chambers, fine cuisine, and the highest quality of personalized service await you here at the Clinic. Your satisfaction is our highest priority, and you can rest assured that we'll work hard to make your stay a comfortable and pleasant one.

YOUR PRIVACY IS OUR PRIORITY
Here in the Clinic's exclusive VIP Wing, you'll enjoy the highest level of privacy and security that we offer. Access is limited to a select group of professional and courteous Clinic staff who are here to serve you. No information, including your presence here, will be shared with anyone beyond your attending physician and support staff. In addition, your medical records will be kept in our most secure database, with the maximum level of protection from outside intrusion.

A STRESS-FREE RECOVERY
Here at the Clinic, the brightest minds in medicine and the most sophisticated technology and research combine to ensure that you receive the best care anywhere. The promise of a stress-free recovery is our commitment to you, our valued guest. Whatever you're here for, there's simply no better place to be.

Maintenance Issue 0412-09-ERL

Logged By: K. Osterholt, Ship's Engineer (GPF-09811)

Issue: Grav Drive Navigation Drift

Description: Captain logged that jumps were off by a few thousand kilometers. Discovered that one of the drive coils was misfiring two ticks off polarity axis.

Solution: Drive Coil LR-07 replaced from existing storage. Requisition for new coil placed.

Status: Closed

Logged By: K. Osterholt, Ship's Engineer (GPF-09811)

Issue: Exterior Running Light Failure - Ventral Position 06 (VP06-RL)

Description: VP06-RL not emitting any pings.

Solution: VP06-RL replaced from existing storage. Requisition for new light placed.

Status: Closed

Maintenance Issue 0207-10-ERL

Logged By: K. Osterholt, Ship's Engineer (GPF-09811)

Issue: Intrusive Odor

Description: Rotten egg smell reported to be emitting from the interior ventilation system. Did a sniff trace and found that one of the interior sewage lines had fractured and was leaking into vent shaft R23-SE-790.

Solution: Did a quick spot-weld and some heat-pipe wrapping. Should hold.

Status: Closed

Maintenance Issue 0602-10-ERL

Logged By: K. Osterholt, Ship's Engineer (GPF-09811)

Issue: Hiding My Stuff!

Description: People don't know how to keep their hands to themselves and they're constantly taking my stuff.

Solution: Sealed my stuff away in Engine Room, in the Control Room safe. Code is KO-098097375.

Status: Closed

Logged By: K. Osterholt, Ship's Engineer (GPF-09811)
